Rationale: Mandating threat modeling is part of the corporate policy and standards.
Integrating TM into the SDLC lifecycle is precisely the spirit of maturity level 3 for Threat Modeling in SAMM.

Allocating resources for TM seems to map best to Organization and Culture Level 1.
Corporate policies should clearly define how much time should be allocated to this (e.g., point system for each sprint).
Mandatory TM trainings should be part of the education and guidance Level 1 program
Adaptive / specialized trainings are part of the Level 2 SAMM program
Active practice is perhaps part of the actuall threat modeling Level 1, but I'm not 100% sure about this.
Support structure for TM is part of the Security Champions programme levels 1 and 2.
Training based on internal standards and policies including demonstration of tools and techniques are from Levels 2 and 3 of SAMM Training and Awareness stream.
Most closely related activity in SAMM is the idea of having a portal updated regularly with best practices. Level 2 is also somewhat relevant.
I don't think SAMM has anything on this.
Definitely not in SAMM and should be added to it. Too often I see the "hero threat modeler antipattern
Not in SAMM
Not in SAMM
Portfolio prioritization is all about having risk profiles.
Notes: Not sure whether L1 or L2

Rationale:
Ingesting architecture for analysis is all about Architectural Validation. 
Threat intelligence sources are essential for additional information regarding threat intelligence (less relevant).
Threats and patterns catalog is all about Architectural Mitigation in SAMM. Level 3 is the most suitable pick here.
Standard threat modeling is the gist of SAMM's Threat Modeling Level 2.
Although iterativeness is mentioned at Level 1 regular threat modeling is something mandated at Level 3 of Threat Modeling stream in SAMM.
Not in SAMM
This isn't explicitly mentioned in SAMM but it largely belongs to the collective development and sharing of security know-how in the teams.
Tools are explicitly required for this activity in SAMM.
Not in SAMM

It is implicit in SAMM that security requirements should be elicited from various sources including TM.
Security requirements derived from TM should be thrown into automated tests.
Abuse cases should be also constructed based on the TM (and vice versa - they should close the loop to TM).
Metrics in Defect Management is the best match for this capability. Level  3 is picked because the capability focuses on closing the loop with other activities.
Notes: Level 2 could be a match as well

Rationale: Perfect mapping to application risk profiles in SAMM. Level  3 is picked because the capability focuses on closing the loop with other activities.
Notes: Level 2 could be a match as well

Rationale: Weak mapping.
Specialized training is a match here, although the mapping is weak.
Not in SAMM
Knowledge and experience sharing is part of the Secure Centers of Excellence and the searchable portal in SAMM, albeit the connection is relatively weak.
Not in SAMM
This capability is about basic metrics for TM effort vs ROI. Maps perfectly to Measure and Improve Level 1.
Clearly Measure and Improve. I've picked Level 2 because this capability makes me think more of KPIs rather than just having the metrics.
Notes: Level 1could be a match as well
Honestly, I have no idea what this capability means.

Rationale: Although SAMM doesn't mention anything about threat modeling in Create and Promote, this capability clearly fits in Strategy and Metrics practice.
Continuous improvements to the TM program is part of Level 3 Threat Modeling Stream in SAMM.
Metrics-driven improvement and adoption fits Measure and Improve Level 3.
Central points to share experience fits the Security Center of Excellence in SAMM.
